content: Is RLS still maintained? It is currently blocking us from syncing Clippy back to rustc #91154. But to do this we would have to put in some work in bumping the nightly version in RLS by multiple months (current nightly is from sometime in may).
@Igor Matuszewski is in charge of maintaining RLS. I don't know how active they've been lately.
Hey sorry, I’ve been on a mental health PTO recently
So I took a step back for a while, but I’ve been planning to start catching up in December
@flip1995 I think in the meantime you could pin RLS to an older version of clippy
(that should be easier for @Igor Matuszewski to review than bumping the nightly version by 3 months)
If that’s possible then that would help a lot
I think when testing RLS in the Rust repo, it uses the latest Clippy version and not the one linked in the Cargo.toml? Otherwise, I can't explain how we get this error
that seems ... strange? is it patching cargo.toml or something?
So we would have to bump the Clippy version to at least the point, where this function was changed. This then leads to this issue: cargo zulip stream
This can be fixed by bumping the edition of RLS to 2021. But that in turn (to do it cleanly) would mean to bump the nightly version to where edition 2021 was stabilized.
Or I could fix the linked cargo bug...
I try to investigate further. I don't want to give you a big review @Igor Matuszewski if I can avoid it.

So looking into this more showed that getting around a RLS update wasn't really possible (sorry). I first tried to only do a minimal necessary nightly bump to 2021-09-02. But this let to further errors with the clippy and rustfmt dep. So I bumped the nightly to today 2021-11-24. The diff isn't too bad though, +14 -23 excluding the Cargo.lock changes. It's also pretty straight forward. @Igor Matuszewski could you give this a quick review rust-lang/rls#1753, please?
